<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of ahc_echo:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
ahc_echo (void *cls,
          struct MHD_Connection *connection,
          const char *url,
          const char *method,
          const char *version,
          const char *upload_data,
          size_t *upload_data_size,
          void **req_cls)
{
  static int aptr;
  struct MHD_Response *response;
  enum MHD_Result ret;
  (void) cls;               /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) url;               /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) version;           /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) upload_data;       /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) upload_data_size;  /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */

  if (0 != strcmp (method, "GET"))
    return MHD_NO;              /* unexpected method */
  if (&aptr != *req_cls)
  {
    /* do never respond on first call */
    *req_cls = &aptr;
    return MHD_YES;
  }
  *req_cls = NULL;                  /* reset when done */
  response = MHD_create_response_for_upgrade (&uh_cb,
                                              NULL);

  MHD_add_response_header (response,
                           MHD_HTTP_HEADER_UPGRADE,
                           "Echo Server");
  ret = MHD_queue_response (connection,
                            MHD_HTTP_SWITCHING_PROTOCOLS,
                            response);
  MHD_destroy_response (response);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
*req_cls = &aptr;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.8 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The code writes to the object pointed to by the pointer parameter (assigning a value to *req_cls), not to the parameter variable req_cls itself. MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 allows modification of the object referred to by a pointer parameter but forbids modifying the pointer parameter itself. Thus the fragment *req_cls = &aptr; does not violate Rule 17.8. (An actual violation would be assigning to req_cls itself, e.g. req_cls = &aptr; or req_cls = NULL;.)
